elements.title: Product-Category Label Before Any Detail
elements.problem: Taline encountered a Craigslist ad for a Split Lease listing and had zero understanding of what kind of product she was looking at. Her very first substantive question -- 'is it for a certain time?' (0:52) -- reveals she could not even categorize the listing. She believed she was responding to a standard full-time rental. The listing detail (location, price, photos) is meaningless if the guest does not first understand the product category. Information was structured detail-first with no category label, causing Taline to invest three minutes of phone conversation before learning this was not a traditional rental. When information hierarchy fails at the category level, all downstream evaluation is built on a false premise.
elements.solution: Structure every guest-facing touchpoint so the product category label appears before any listing detail. The first piece of information a guest encounters -- whether on a Craigslist ad, a social media post, or a landing page -- must be a plain-language category statement: 'Part-time rental: 2-5 nights per week. Not a full-time lease.' This label must precede the address, the price, the photos, and every other detail. The category label is the root node of the information hierarchy; without it, every child node is misinterpreted.

evidence.quote: I just wanted to know, like that, is it for a certain time?
evidence.insight: Taline's first question is not about price, location, or amenities -- it is about the fundamental nature of the product. The information hierarchy of whatever she saw on Craigslist failed to communicate the most basic category-level fact.

evidence.quote: What I'm really looking for something for like two months... Yeah, my full time.
evidence.insight: Three minutes into the call, Taline still believes this is a full-time rental. The absence of a category label at discovery allowed her to build a complete (and incorrect) mental model of the product.

evidence.quote: What the students thought might be the need and what they actually found turned out to be two very different things.
evidence.insight: The d.school team discovered that misaligned expectations at the start corrupt all subsequent work. For information architecture, this means the category-level label must be the first node in the hierarchy -- it is the frame that makes all other information interpretable.

evidence.quote: Like so many great tales, this story starts with a miscommunication.
evidence.insight: Miscommunication at the category level is architectural, not cosmetic. The fix is not better copywriting on the listing body -- it is restructuring the information hierarchy so the category label is the entry point.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Product category is primary (must be the first thing read). Location and price range are secondary (provide context within the category). Listing specifics (photos, amenities, host details) are tertiary (meaningful only after category and context are understood). The category label must appear in the first visual scan zone of any touchpoint -- above the fold, before the image, before the price.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Disclose category before detail, always. On external ads (Craigslist, social): category label is the headline or first line. On the platform landing page: category explanation with a visual (e.g., a weekly calendar showing M-F shaded) appears before any listing grid. On individual listing pages: category badge or tag is visible in the first viewport without scrolling. The guest must be able to self-select or self-exclude within 5 seconds of first contact.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The category label must be 10 words or fewer: 'Part-time rental: stay 2-5 nights per week.' No jargon ('multi-local,' 'periodic tenancy,' 'utilization-based'). No compound sentences. One concept per label: this is part-time, not full-time.
scan_order: Price range (per night or estimated monthly)
exclude: Platform brand story or mission statement at discovery
Host biography at discovery
Detailed amenity lists before category comprehension
Terms like 'multi-local guest' or 'repeat renter' that require prior knowledge of the model

elements.title: Progressive Price Disclosure Across Three Tiers
elements.problem: Taline asked the most direct evaluation question a guest can ask -- 'So I just want to know how much would it cost' (2:51) -- and received no answer. Bryant could only say 'I have sort of a general idea, but not exact, just because typically these nightly pricing will be set specific on the situation' (5:33-5:50). Pricing is the single most important variable for a budget-constrained guest making a life decision, yet the information architecture provides zero pricing information at search, zero at listing evaluation, and defers it entirely to a future agent-host conversation. The guest is asked to invest time, adapt her needs, and wait for a callback -- all before seeing a single number. This is an information sequencing failure: the guest needs pricing information early (to decide whether to proceed), but the system provides it late (after human mediation).
elements.solution: Structure pricing information into three progressive tiers that match the guest's decision journey. Tier 1 (Search/Discovery): Show a per-night price range on every listing or ad -- e.g., '$55-$85/night depending on schedule.' This is imprecise but sufficient for budget qualification. Tier 2 (Listing Evaluation): When a guest specifies a stay pattern (e.g., M-F, 8 weeks), show an estimated monthly total based on the range midpoint with a clear 'estimate' label -- e.g., 'Estimated: ~$1,400/month for 5 nights/week. Final price confirmed by host.' Tier 3 (Proposal): Show the exact host-confirmed price for the specific arrangement. Each tier adds precision, but the guest always has a price signal to work with. The guest never encounters a stage where the answer to 'how much?' is 'I do not know yet.'

evidence.quote: So I just want to know how much would it cost.
evidence.insight: The most direct possible pricing question. The guest needs this number to make a life decision involving her child's school commute, two jobs, and a lease deadline. An information architecture that cannot surface any price signal at this moment fails at its most basic function.

evidence.quote: I have sort of a general idea, but not exact, just because typically these nightly pricing will be set specific on the situation.
evidence.insight: Even the agent acknowledges having 'a general idea.' This general idea is the Tier 1 price range that should be visible on the listing itself. The information exists but is locked behind human mediation rather than structured into the information hierarchy.

evidence.quote: These kinds of realizations don't come from just understanding an idea -- they come through the experience of trying, and failing, and trying again.
evidence.insight: Experimentation requires information to experiment with. A pricing calculator where the guest adjusts nights-per-week and sees cost changes is experiential learning applied to a booking decision. Without any price signal, there is nothing to experiment with.

evidence.quote: When faced with an open-ended challenge that doesn't have one fixed, right solution, we can all feel like beginners.
evidence.insight: Variable pricing is an open-ended challenge for the guest. Presenting it as opacity ('price depends on situation') makes the guest feel helpless. Presenting it as a range with interactive exploration ('adjust your pattern, see your estimate') makes the guest feel empowered within the variability.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Price range is primary at search (enables budget qualification). Estimated monthly total is primary at listing evaluation (enables life-planning math). Exact confirmed price is primary at proposal (enables final commitment decision). At each stage, the most precise available price information occupies the primary position in the visual hierarchy.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Tier 1 (range) is always visible, from first contact through proposal. Tier 2 (estimate) appears when the guest inputs a pattern, and is clearly labeled as an estimate. Tier 3 (confirmed) replaces the estimate only when the host confirms exact terms. The guest never sees a screen with no price information -- the question is precision level, not presence/absence. Transition from Tier 2 to Tier 3 should be visually highlighted ('Your estimate has been confirmed by the host: $1,350/month').
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: One price number per context. At search: per-night range (two numbers max: '$55-$85/night'). At listing evaluation: one estimated monthly total ('~$1,400/month'). At proposal: one confirmed monthly total with a breakdown available on tap/click. Never show nightly rate AND weekly rate AND monthly rate simultaneously -- pick the unit that matches the guest's planning horizon.
scan_order: What is included vs. additional costs
exclude: Pricing methodology explanations at search or listing evaluation (save for FAQ)
Host-side pricing logic (utilization rates, discount tiers) during guest evaluation
Comparisons to hotel or Airbnb nightly rates (different product category)
The phrase 'pricing will be set specific on the situation' or any equivalent that communicates zero information

elements.title: Mismatch-to-Alternative Bridge Structure
elements.problem: When Bryant told Taline 'unfortunately I won't be able to help you with that... he's not interested in full-time rentals' (3:09), Taline faced a binary dead end: her need was rejected with no immediately visible alternative. The information she received was structured as a negation ('we cannot do this') without a paired affirmation ('but we can do this'). The transition from rejection to alternative took 45 seconds of human conversation, during which Bryant suggested 'five nights a week' (3:21) and Taline adapted. In a self-service flow, the negation would be the last thing the guest sees before leaving. Information architecture must never present a negation without a structurally paired alternative. The negation and the alternative must appear as a single information unit, not as a sequence where the guest might leave between the two.
elements.solution: Design every mismatch moment as a bridge structure: the 'cannot' and the 'can' must appear together as one visual and informational unit. When a guest's stated need does not match what is available, the interface must simultaneously show: (1) acknowledgment of the stated need ('You are looking for a full-time, 7-night stay'), (2) the constraint ('This listing is available for part-time stays of 2-5 nights per week'), and (3) the nearest viable alternative with a concrete example ('Many guests stay Monday through Friday and spend weekends elsewhere. Here is what that looks like for you: [pattern + estimated cost]'). These three components must appear as a single card or panel, not as a multi-step sequence. The guest should never see the constraint without simultaneously seeing the alternative.

evidence.quote: Unfortunately I won't be able to help you with that. So I work with Ken specifically to find these types of guests. So he's not interested in full-time rentals.
evidence.insight: The rejection is delivered without an immediately paired alternative. There is a gap -- several seconds of conversation -- before Bryant suggests M-F as an option. In a self-service interface, that gap is where the guest clicks away. The information must be restructured so rejection and alternative are one unit.

evidence.quote: Five nights a week is likely something that you would be interested in... Five nights and then I can do the weekends at my mom.
evidence.insight: Bryant's suggestion of a specific alternative (5 nights) is what saved the interaction. Taline immediately mapped it to her life ('weekends at my mom'). The alternative must be specific and concrete -- not 'consider fewer nights' but 'Monday through Friday, estimated $X/month.'

evidence.quote: None of these assignments has to be used exactly as written. Each is meant to be tinkered with, adapted, and remixed.
evidence.insight: The d.school principle of tinkering and adaptation applies to the guest's stay pattern. The information architecture should present the alternative not as a fixed counter-offer but as a starting point the guest can adjust: 'Start with M-F. Adjust nights to see how price changes.'

evidence.quote: We're hard on work but soft on people, and we don't confuse kindness with weakness.
evidence.insight: Being 'soft on people' in information architecture means never presenting a constraint as a bare rejection. The constraint is the work (hard and clear); the alternative is the softness (supportive and immediate). Both must be present simultaneously.

elements.hierarchy_principle: The alternative is primary (what the guest CAN do). The constraint is secondary (why the original request does not fit). The acknowledgment of the guest's stated need is tertiary (shows the system heard them). In visual hierarchy: the alternative should be the largest, most prominent element. The constraint is a supporting explanation. The acknowledgment is a small header that provides context. The guest's eye should land on the solution, not the problem.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The bridge structure appears inline at the moment of mismatch -- no modal, no separate page, no 'learn more' link. It is embedded in the evaluation flow itself. If the guest indicates 7 nights/week, the bridge appears immediately below or beside their input, not after a submission or a loading screen. If the guest adjusts their input to match an available pattern, the bridge dissolves and the normal listing evaluation flow continues seamlessly.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The bridge must contain no more than three components: (1) what the guest wanted, in 5 words ('You want a 7-night stay'), (2) what is available, in 8 words or fewer ('Available: 2-5 nights/week'), (3) one concrete alternative with a number ('Monday-Friday, ~$1,400/month'). No paragraphs of explanation. No links to FAQ. No 'why' explanations unless the guest requests them via an expandable detail.
scan_order: Concrete alternative pattern with estimated cost
exclude: Apologies or regret language ('unfortunately,' 'sorry we cannot')
Explanations of why the host prefers part-time guests
Platform business model descriptions
Links to other pages or FAQs as the primary response to a mismatch

elements.title: Post-Call Summary as Structured Information Artifact
elements.problem: Taline's call ended with no written record of what was discussed. The only information artifact from the entire interaction is whatever Taline remembers from a phone call she took while driving home in traffic (0:35). Bryant said 'I can talk to him and talk to him about your situation. And I get back to you on that' (5:22-5:33) and 'feel free to text me' (6:13-6:20). Taline now holds the following information only in working memory: the host's name (Ken), the area (North Bergen/Union City), the adapted pattern (M-F), the pricing opacity (unknown, depends on situation), and the next step (Bryant will call back, no timeline). There is no digital artifact she can return to, review, share with a family member, or use to track status. The information generated during the call exists nowhere except in two people's fallible memories. For a guest making a life decision under time pressure, this is an information architecture failure: the system generated valuable information and then failed to persist it.
elements.solution: After every substantive guest interaction (call, chat, or form submission), automatically generate and send a structured summary. The summary must be: (1) Sent within 5 minutes of the interaction ending, via text or email. (2) Structured with clear labeled sections, not a paragraph of prose. Sections: 'What You Are Looking For' (adapted pattern, dates, area), 'What Happens Next' (specific next step with a timeline), 'Your Contact' (agent name and contact info), 'Status' (current step in the process). (3) Include a link to a status page where the guest can check progress without texting the agent. (4) Editable by the guest: if Taline wants to change her start date from Dec 15 to Dec 20, she can update it in the summary rather than trying to remember to mention it when Bryant calls back.

evidence.quote: I can talk to him and talk to him about your situation. And I get back to you on that.
evidence.insight: The next step is verbal and unstructured. There is no timeline ('when?'), no confirmation ('here is what I heard'), and no tracking mechanism ('check status here'). The information about what happens next is the most important post-call information and it was communicated in the least persistent medium: a spoken sentence.

evidence.quote: Let me know if you have any questions about the space or anything else that comes up, feel free to text me.
evidence.insight: The only post-call channel is unstructured texting. This places the burden on the guest to remember what to ask and when. A structured summary inverts this: the system reminds the guest what was discussed and prompts next actions.

evidence.quote: We try things out before we know exactly what will happen, and then we spend time thinking and talking about what, exactly, just happened.
evidence.insight: The d.school principle of reflecting on what happened is an information architecture principle: generate an artifact that captures what happened so the participant can review and reflect rather than relying on memory. The post-call summary is this reflective artifact.

evidence.quote: But success is never about a single moment of insight.
evidence.insight: If the interaction is not persisted as a structured artifact, then success depends on whether both parties perfectly remember a single phone call. Structured persistence turns a fragile single-moment dependency into a durable information record.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Next step with timeline is primary (what happens now and when). Captured request summary is secondary (what the guest is looking for). Contact information is tertiary (how to reach someone if needed). Status indicator is always visible (where in the process the guest currently stands). The guest's eye should hit the next step first, not a recap of what they already know.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The summary is sent proactively (push, not pull) immediately after the interaction. The initial message is concise: next step + timeline + link to full summary. The full summary page discloses additional detail progressively: top section is status and next step (always visible), middle section is request details (expandable), bottom section is interaction history (expandable). As the process advances, the summary updates: 'Step 2: Host reviewing your request' becomes 'Step 3: Pricing proposal ready -- review now.'
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The push notification (text/email) must be under 50 words. The full summary page must have no more than 4 labeled sections. Each section header must be a question the guest would ask: 'What happens next?', 'What did I ask for?', 'Who is my contact?', 'Where am I in the process?' No section should contain more than 3 bullet points.
scan_order: Status indicator (which step in the process)
exclude: Platform marketing or onboarding prompts in the summary
Detailed explanations of the pricing model
Host-side process details (agent talking to host, internal reviews)
Any information that requires the guest to take action before the promised next step occurs

elements.title: Life-Context Commute Layer on Listing Information
elements.problem: Taline's evaluation of any listing depends on factors invisible in a standard listing page: her son's school location, her weekday job commute, her Saturday job commute, and her mother's house as a weekend fallback. She told Bryant: 'I don't want to stay at my mom because my job for me to commute and have to pick up my son from school far from me' (4:25-4:41). The listing information architecture shows address, photos, amenities, and price -- none of which answer Taline's actual evaluation question: 'Does this listing work for my daily logistics?' Listing information is structured around the property. Taline's decision is structured around her life. There is a fundamental mismatch between how information is organized (property-centric) and how the guest evaluates (life-centric).
elements.solution: Add a life-context information layer to listing pages that translates property attributes into guest-life implications. When a guest provides key locations (workplace, child's school, fallback home), every listing page should display: (1) Commute times from the listing to each key location, calculated for the guest's likely travel mode and time of day. (2) A visual commute map showing the listing in relation to the guest's key locations. (3) A compatibility indicator: 'This listing is 12 min from your workplace and 8 min from your son's school' or 'Warning: This listing is 45 min from your son's school during morning drop-off.' This layer sits on top of the standard listing information, transforming a property-centric page into a life-centric evaluation tool.

evidence.quote: I don't want to stay at my mom because my job for me to commute and have to pick up my son from school far from me.
evidence.insight: The listing evaluation is fundamentally about commute geometry: Taline needs a location where she can get to work AND pick up her son from school. No amount of property detail (square footage, amenities) matters if the commute does not work. The information hierarchy must place commute compatibility above property details for guests with location constraints.

evidence.quote: I live in Jersey and my job is literally 30 minutes from my house.
evidence.insight: Taline evaluates housing in terms of commute minutes, not neighborhood names or zip codes. The information layer should speak in the same unit the guest uses: minutes, not miles or neighborhoods.

evidence.quote: Engaging people intentionally to learn more about their lives and spark new ideas.
evidence.insight: The d.school principle of learning about people's lives maps to an information architecture principle: the system must capture life-context data and use it to reshape how information is presented. Generic listing information serves generic guests. Life-context-aware listing information serves real people.

evidence.quote: When you design, you shape the world for others, whether you're redesigning the evening routine for your family or an entire public health system.
evidence.insight: Split Lease is literally shaping Taline's family evening routine: where she picks up her son, how long the commute takes, whether she can get dinner ready on time. The listing information must acknowledge this by surfacing life-relevant data, not just property data.

elements.hierarchy_principle: For guests who have provided life-context data: commute compatibility is primary (answers 'does this work for my life?'). Property basics (bedrooms, bathroom, kitchen) are secondary (answers 'is the space adequate?'). Amenities and extras are tertiary (answers 'what else is nice about this?'). For guests who have not provided life-context data: standard property information is primary, with a prompt to add key locations to see personalized commute times.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Life-context data is collected once (during onboarding or first listing view) via a simple prompt: 'Add your workplace and your child's school to see commute times on every listing.' Once provided, the commute layer appears automatically on every listing page. The commute layer is visually distinct from property information (different background, icon set) so the guest can scan between 'life fit' and 'property details' without confusion. Commute times update if the guest changes their key locations.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 commute destinations displayed per listing (e.g., workplace, child's school, fallback home). Each destination shows one number: commute time in minutes for the most likely mode and time. No route options, no transit comparisons, no distance in miles -- just minutes. A 'see details' expansion can show mode options and route maps for guests who want deeper exploration.
scan_order: Commute times to key locations (workplace, school)
Compatibility indicator (works / warning / does not work)
exclude: Distance in miles or kilometers (use minutes only)
Transit route details on the primary listing view
Commute comparisons to other listings on the same page (save for a comparison tool)
Neighborhood descriptions that do not reference the guest's specific locations

elements.title: Stay Pattern as Interactive Visual Before Text
elements.problem: The Split Lease model is difficult to explain in words. Bryant spent from 1:06 to 1:51 (45 seconds) trying to describe it verbally: 'repeat renters or multi local guests... part of the week each week, part of the month each month, any sort of like irregular repeat stay... like a hybrid worker... Monday to Friday each week as an example... couple of weeks a month.' Despite this verbal explanation, Taline still responded with 'what I'm really looking for something for like two months... my full time' (2:03-3:02), indicating the verbal explanation did not land. The concept is spatial and temporal -- it is about which nights of the week you are there and which you are not. Text and speech are poor media for conveying temporal patterns. The information architecture relies on the wrong modality (words) for a concept that is inherently visual (a calendar pattern).
elements.solution: Present the stay pattern as an interactive weekly calendar visual at every point where the model needs to be understood. The visual shows a 7-day week with selectable night blocks. Default state: Monday through Friday shaded (the most common pattern). The guest can tap/click to add or remove nights and see the estimated cost update in real time. This visual replaces the verbal explanation ('part of the week, each week') with a direct spatial representation. At discovery, the visual is static and illustrative ('This is how Split Lease works: [M-F shaded calendar]'). At listing evaluation, the visual becomes interactive ('Select your nights'). At proposal creation, the visual confirms the selected pattern ('Your stay: Mon-Fri, starting Dec 15').

evidence.quote: It's a couple of times a week... flexible... repeat renters or multi local guests... part of the week each week, part of the month each month... like a hybrid worker... Monday to Friday each week as an example.
evidence.insight: Bryant's 45-second verbal explanation covers the concept thoroughly but fails to establish comprehension -- Taline immediately responds with a full-time request. Verbal/textual explanation of a temporal pattern is cognitively expensive and easy to misinterpret. A visual calendar pattern communicates the same concept in under 3 seconds.

evidence.quote: Five nights a week is likely something that you would be interested in... Five nights and then I can do the weekends at my mom.
evidence.insight: Taline understood the model only when it was reduced to a specific, concrete pattern ('five nights a week') that she could map to her own life. The interactive calendar visual does this systematically: it always shows a specific, concrete pattern, not an abstract description.

evidence.quote: The experience of doing these assignments is the value you will take away. The emphasis is not on mastering tools or technique.
evidence.insight: The d.school emphasizes experiential understanding over explanation. An interactive calendar that the guest manipulates is experiential -- they learn the model by using it, not by reading about it. The information architecture should favor interactive visual explanation over textual description.

evidence.quote: These kinds of realizations don't come from just understanding an idea -- they come through the experience of trying, and failing, and trying again.
evidence.insight: Letting the guest tap nights on and off in a calendar and see the cost change is 'trying' the model. Comprehension of the Split Lease model should come from interaction with a visual tool, not from reading a definition.

elements.hierarchy_principle: The calendar visual is primary at every stage where the model needs to be understood. Text explanation is secondary (available below or beside the visual for guests who want it). Detailed terms (nightly rate, minimum stays, blackout dates) are tertiary (available on expansion after the guest has engaged with the visual). The visual answers the question 'what does this look like in my week?' before text answers 'how does the pricing work?'
elements.disclosure_pattern: Stage 1 (Discovery): Static calendar visual with M-F shaded, labeled 'Most guests stay like this.' No interaction needed -- purely illustrative. Stage 2 (Listing Evaluation): Interactive calendar where the guest selects nights and sees an estimated cost per month. The calendar defaults to M-F but is adjustable. Stage 3 (Proposal): Confirmed calendar showing the agreed pattern, with exact pricing and dates. The visual evolves from illustrative to interactive to confirmatory across phases, maintaining spatial consistency so the guest always recognizes it.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The calendar visual must show exactly 7 days (one week) with night-blocks that are either on or off. No monthly views at first encounter (too much data). No hourly breakdowns. Each night is a binary: staying or not staying. The estimated cost is a single number that updates when the pattern changes. Maximum information density: 7 binary states + 1 cost number = 8 data points.
scan_order: Weekly calendar visual with pattern highlighted
Estimated cost for the displayed pattern
Adjust prompt ('Tap nights to change your pattern')
Text explanation of the model (below the visual)
exclude: Monthly calendar views at discovery or initial evaluation (too much information)
Hourly check-in/check-out details on the pattern visual
Pricing breakdowns per night on the pattern visual (single monthly total only)
Abstract descriptions of the model without a visual anchor

elements.title: Urgency-Responsive Information Sequencing
elements.problem: Taline is under acute time pressure: her lease is ending, she needs to move by December 15th, she is calling while driving home from work in traffic (0:35), and she has a child whose school commute depends on where she lives. The information architecture presents information in the same sequence regardless of the guest's urgency level. But an urgent guest needs different information first than a browsing guest. Taline does not need to understand the Split Lease philosophy, read host bios, or explore amenity photos. She needs three things in rapid sequence: (1) Can this work for my situation? (2) Can I afford it? (3) How fast can I move in? The current architecture buries these answers behind verbal explanations, pricing opacity, and agent-mediated timelines. An urgent guest with a concrete deadline processes information in a fundamentally different scan pattern than a casual explorer.
elements.solution: Detect or allow guests to self-declare urgency, and restructure the information hierarchy accordingly. When a guest indicates urgency (e.g., 'I need to move by [date]' or selects 'I need housing soon' in a form), the information sequence shifts: (1) Availability and move-in date come first ('Available from Dec 10. Move-in possible within 48 hours of confirmation.'). (2) Price estimate comes second ('Estimated: $65/night for Mon-Fri stays, ~$1,400/month.'). (3) Location compatibility comes third ('12 min from [guest's workplace].'). (4) Property details come fourth (photos, amenities, house rules). For non-urgent guests, the default sequence (property details, model explanation, pricing exploration) is preserved. The architecture adapts its disclosure order to the guest's context.

evidence.quote: Don't coming home from traffic.
evidence.insight: Taline is calling during her commute. She is not in a context where she can browse a website, compare listings, or read long descriptions. She needs fast, essential information delivered in a sequence that matches her decision priorities: availability, then cost, then location.

evidence.quote: So I just want to know how much would it cost.
evidence.insight: Taline cuts through the model explanation to ask the question that matters for her urgency: cost. Her information sequencing priority is clear -- she wants price before philosophy. The architecture should respect this by presenting price early for urgent guests.

evidence.quote: The world is changing too quickly to learn everything you need to know about life while you're in school.
evidence.insight: Applied to information architecture: an urgent guest cannot learn everything about the platform before making a decision. The architecture must surface decision-critical information first and defer educational content. Learning about the platform model can happen after the immediate need is addressed, not before.

evidence.quote: Maybe it was a challenge you took on following a promotion at work, the search for an apartment in a new city, or an effort to organize your neighbors to deal with a block-wide problem.
evidence.insight: The book explicitly names 'the search for an apartment in a new city' as an open-ended challenge that provokes beginner anxiety. For Taline, this anxiety is compounded by a deadline. The information architecture must reduce this anxiety by front-loading the answers to her most pressing questions.

elements.hierarchy_principle: For urgent guests: availability and timeline are primary ('Can I move in by my deadline?'). Cost estimate is secondary ('Can I afford this?'). Location fit is tertiary ('Does this work for my commute?'). Property details are quaternary ('What is the space like?'). For browsing guests, the standard hierarchy applies. The key architectural decision is that urgency reshuffles the information stack, not the information itself -- all the same content exists, but the scan order changes.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Urgency is detected via one of three signals: (1) guest self-declares a move-in date or selects 'I need housing soon,' (2) guest arrives from an urgent-coded channel (e.g., Craigslist housing-needed post), or (3) guest behavior indicates urgency (rapid page progression, short time on model explanation pages). Once urgency is detected, the listing page restructures: availability banner at top, price estimate immediately below, commute times third, property details below the fold. Non-urgent guests see the default layout. The guest can toggle between modes ('Show me the essentials' vs. 'Show me everything').
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: For urgent guests, the above-the-fold content must answer exactly three questions in three data points: (1) Available by your date? Yes/No. (2) Estimated cost: $X/month. (3) Commute to your workplace: X minutes. Everything else is below the fold. Maximum 3 data points in the primary scan zone for urgent guests.
scan_order: Availability confirmation relative to guest's deadline
Estimated monthly cost for their likely pattern
exclude: Platform model explanations in the primary scan zone for urgent guests
Host biography or hosting philosophy for urgent guests
Detailed amenity lists above the fold for urgent guests
Any content that requires more than 10 seconds to process before the guest can answer 'should I proceed?'
